title: Age, Transfer & Excess-Shortage Problems
topic: Age Problems, Difference Unchanged, Give and Take, Excess and Shortage
subject: Mathematics

questions.question: A teacher has some sweets. If she gives 5 sweets to each pupil, she will have 12 sweets left. If she gives 7 sweets to each pupil, she will be short of 8 sweets. How many pupils are there?
questions.explanation: Difference per pupil: 7 - 5 = 2 sweets. Total difference: 12 excess + 8 shortage = 20 sweets. Pupils: 20 ÷ 2 = 10 pupils.

questions.question: Maya is 14 years old. Her brother is 6 years old. How many years ago was Maya three times as old as her brother?
questions.explanation: Let x = years ago. Maya then: 14 - x, Brother then: 6 - x. Equation: 14 - x = 3(6 - x) → 14 - x = 18 - 3x → 2x = 4 → x = 2 years ago. Check: 12 = 3 × 4 ✓

questions.question: There are some cookies to be shared. If each child gets 4 cookies, there will be 15 cookies left. If each child gets 6 cookies, there will be 3 cookies left. How many children are there?
questions.explanation: Difference per child: 6 - 4 = 2 cookies. Difference in leftovers: 15 - 3 = 12 cookies. Children: 12 ÷ 2 = 6 children.

questions.question: Ryan has $96 and Sam has $48. Ryan gives some money to Sam so that Ryan has $24 more than Sam. How much did Ryan give?
questions.explanation: Total money: $96 + $48 = $144 (unchanged). After transfer: Ryan = Sam + $24. So Sam + $24 + Sam = $144 → 2 × Sam = $120 → Sam = $60. Ryan gave: $60 - $48 = $12.

questions.question: A grandfather is 68 years old. His grandson is 8 years old. In how many years will the grandfather be 5 times as old as his grandson?
questions.explanation: Age difference: 68 - 8 = 60 years (unchanged). When grandfather is 5 times grandson's age, difference = 4 parts. Each part = 60 ÷ 4 = 15 years (grandson's age then). Years needed: 15 - 8 = 7 years.

questions.question: Some pencils are to be distributed. If each student gets 3 pencils, 22 pencils remain. If each student gets 5 pencils, 4 pencils remain. How many pencils are there altogether?
questions.explanation: Difference per student: 5 - 3 = 2 pencils. Difference in leftovers: 22 - 4 = 18 pencils. Students: 18 ÷ 2 = 9 students. Total pencils: 9 × 3 + 22 = 27 + 22 = 49 pencils.

questions.question: Cindy has 3 times as many books as David. If Cindy gives 18 books to David, they will have the same number of books. How many books did Cindy have at first?
questions.explanation: Let David = x, Cindy = 3x. After: Cindy = 3x - 18, David = x + 18. Equal: 3x - 18 = x + 18 → 2x = 36 → x = 18. Cindy: 3 × 18 = 54 books.

questions.question: A group of friends wants to buy a gift. If each contributes $8, they will be short of $10. If each contributes $10, they will have $6 extra. How many friends are there?
questions.explanation: Difference per person: $10 - $8 = $2. Total difference: $10 shortage + $6 excess = $16. Friends: $16 ÷ $2 = 8 friends.

questions.question: Alan is 5 years older than Ben. In 3 years, the sum of their ages will be 31 years. How old is Alan now?
questions.explanation: Let Ben = x, Alan = x + 5. In 3 years: Ben = x + 3, Alan = x + 8. Sum: (x + 3) + (x + 8) = 31 → 2x + 11 = 31 → 2x = 20 → x = 10. Alan now: 10 + 5 = 15 years.

questions.question: There are some oranges. If they are given 4 to each child, 14 oranges remain. If they are given 7 to each child, 2 oranges remain. How many oranges are there?
questions.explanation: Difference per child: 7 - 4 = 3 oranges. Difference in leftovers: 14 - 2 = 12 oranges. Children: 12 ÷ 3 = 4 children. Total oranges: 4 × 4 + 14 = 16 + 14 = 30 oranges. Check: 30 ÷ 7 = 4 R2 ✓

questions.question: Some cupcakes are packed into boxes. If 5 cupcakes are packed in each box, 8 cupcakes are left unpacked. If 8 cupcakes are packed in each box, 2 cupcakes are left unpacked. How many cupcakes are there?
questions.explanation: Numbers with remainder 8 when ÷5: 13, 18, 23, 28, 33, 38... Which has remainder 2 when ÷8? 18 ÷ 8 = 2 R2 ✓. Total cupcakes = 18.

questions.question: A coach has some basketballs. If he gives 3 basketballs to each team, he will have 9 basketballs left. If he gives 5 basketballs to each team, he will have 1 basketball left. How many teams are there?
questions.explanation: Difference per team: 5 - 3 = 2 basketballs. Difference in leftovers: 9 - 1 = 8 basketballs. Teams: 8 ÷ 2 = 4 teams.
